OnlinePlatform.Title: Why an online platform
Cards:
Increase reliability

  • Have consistency checks on data to limit entry errors
  • Limit mistakes in calculation

Step back

  • Encourage geographically remote projects to use the same indicators when measuring comparable events
  • Have mechanisms to compare the value of an indicator on a project, with the same value for all other that collected it

Ease communication

  • Provide direct access to project's data to all departments in the NGO (management, communication, ...)
  • Have single source of truth between headquarters and field project

Standardize

  • Ease turn-over by limiting the number of different tools used across projects
  • Reduce the learning curve required to consult data on a new project

When.Title: When should you use Monitool
When.SubTitle: Monitool plays a role during four stages of a project

Cards.Title: Design of the logical frame
Cards.Text: Monitool provides all others projets logframes, with the list of used indicators and targets for each one of them

Cards.Title: Deployment of monitoring tools
Cards.Text: Explicitely write down the path followed by your data and attach deadlines on data collection

Cards.Title: Periodic follow-up
Cards.Text: Reporting graphs and tables of your choice are available and built with the most up-to-date data

Cards.Title: After closing
Cards.Text: Your project will be archived and available for future references

KeepInMind.Title: Keep in mind
Cards:
Monitool is all about monitoring.

It contributes to the ongoing, continuous and systematic monitoring of the situation and its evolution throughout the life of a project.

Its goal is to help taking decisions, thanks to the continuous follow-up of indicators that provide information on the progress of activities, and their contribution to the expected outputs and outcomes decided for your project.

Even if it can contribute to it, it's primary goal is not to do epidemiologic monitoring, or centralize morbidity sheets which are time-consuming and have little value in project management, specially for projects that support health structure (in opposition with providing direct care).

GettingStarted.Title: Getting started
GettingStarted.SubTitle: Before setting your project up in Monitool, some preliminary steps can help you
Cards: Design your reference project: logical framework with output and outcomes indicators, process indicators can be added if necessary

Use the Indicators summary tool to document all indicators from your reference project, and possibly donor's projects (if they are different)

  • Why: How is each indicator going to help measuring the output or outcome that is expected from your activities? How do you plan on analysing it (graphs, tables, with which periodicity: you need to plan in advance how your data will be used for decision making)
  • How: identify all data and disagregations that will be needed to compute each one of your indicators
  • When, where, by and for whom?

Build a dataflow chart from the indicator's summary to draw how data will flow in your project

  • The data sources organized according to the project's structure
  • Detail collected data and precise disagregations
  • Organize your indicators by logical framework

Guides.Title: Guides & Documents supports
Cards:
• Healthcare project planning (2015)

    Healthcare project planning offers MdM project players a method of planning that is in line with the values reaffirmed and specified in that statement â€“ to provide care and cure, to bear witness and advocate, and to support communities seeking social change.

  • Toolbox for healthcare project planning

    This toolbox contains multiple tools, mostly Excel-based in order to help you formalizing your project's planning.

  • DSP's Monitoring library

    This library contains fact sheets, training documents and position papers connected with monitoring and maintained by the DSP department.

OtherTools.Title: Other tools
Cards:
• Indicator's summary

    Available in the essentials documents for monitoring archive , this tool centralize for all of your indicators the "when", "how", "where", "by whom" and "for whom" the data that you handle should be collected and analized.

  • Dataflow chart

    In the same archive, this tool schematize the path that your data follows, from the form that was used to collect it, to the report or decision making that it enabled.

LogicalFrameworksPageDescription.Line1: A logical framework is a document that describe objectives, expected results, and actities to achieve them, as well as indicators to monitor the advancement of each of those elements
LogicalFrameworksPageDescription.Line2: All indicators have to be computable from the data described in data sources
